title-group.article-title: Redescription of the Mayfly Torleya mikhaili Tiunova, 1995 (Ephemeroptera, Ephemerellidae)

kwd.tp:taxon-name: T. simbalbarensis Selvakumar, Subramanian, Martynov & Jacobus
T. dibruensis Selvakumar, Martynov & Jacobus (Martynov et al. ) 2021

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Redescription of the Mayfly
Torleya mikhaili Tiunova, 1995
( Ephemeroptera , Ephemerellidae )

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Federal Scientific Center of the East Asia Terrestrial Biodiversity, FEB, RAS, Prosp. 100-letiya Vladivostoka 159, Vladivostok 690022 Russia

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
The author collected new material of
T. mikhaili
from different regions of the Russian Far East. Additional characteristics and illustrations are presented here for larvae and adults of the species, as well as first descriptions of the female imago and egg. This species can be distinguished from the other species of the genus in the male adult stage by the shape and configuration of male genitalia; in the larval stage by the shape and setation of larval abdominal terga and forefemora, and features of the claw; and in the egg stage by the relative width and smoothness of surface ridges. The genus
Torleya
is divided into the
major
-group and the
nepalica
-group.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Key words:
Ephemeroptera
,
Torleya
, morphology , eggs

kwd.tp:taxon-name: T. simbalbarensis Selvakumar, Subramanian, Martynov & Jacobus
T. dibruensis Selvakumar, Martynov & Jacobus (Martynov et al. ) 2021

mixed-citation.named-content: Redescription of the Mayfly Torleya mikhaili Tiunova, 1995 (Ephemeroptera, Ephemerellidae)

tp:treatment-sec.p:
was first described by the author (1995) from the south of the Russian Far East, based on the male adult stage, reared from a larva ( Tiunova 1995 ). At that time, only four other species of the genus were known:
Torleya nepalica ( Allen & Edmunds, 1963 )
from Nepal,
T. major ( Klapal√©k, 1905 )
from Europe,
T. padunica Kazlauskas, 1963
from eastern Siberia and
T. japonica Gose, 1980
from Japan. In 2004, a review of
Torleya Lestage species
was carried out that included eight valid
Torleya species
from the Palaearctic and Oriental Regions (Jacobus et al . 2004). The previous five species and three others were included:
Torleya grandipennis Zhou, Su & Gui, 2000
,
T. lutosa Kang &Yang, 1995
, and
T. naga Jacobus &McCafferty
(in Jacobus et al .), 2004. Later, in a work devoted to the revision of Ephemerellidae genera, three more species were added.
Torlyea coheri ( Allen & Edmunds, 1963 )
and
T. lacuna ( Jacobus, McCafferty & Sites, 2007 )
were moved from the genus
Crinitella Allen & Edmunds
, and
T. longforceps ( Gui, Zhou & Su, 1999 )
was transferred from the genus
Serratella Edmunds.
Torleya longforceps
was pleased in this genus on the basis of its male genitalia being similar to those of
T. coheri
,
T. lacuna
, and
T. mikhaili
. At the same time,
T. grandipennis
was moved to the genus
Hyrtanella Allen & Edmunds ( Jacobus & McCafferty 2008 )
. Currently, the genus
Torleya
includes 13 species. This includes two species based on larvae from India‚Äî
T. simbalbarensis Selvakumar, Subramanian, Martynov & Jacobus
(in Martynov et al .), 2021 and
T. dibruensis Selvakumar, Martynov & Jacobus (Martynov et al. ) 2021
‚Äîand
T. elissa ( Jacobus, Zhou & McCafferty 2009 )
from Iran, which was moved from
Serratella
by
Martynov et al . (2023)
.

The increased number of species in the genus
Torleya
over the last thirty years has been associated with the description of new species and the movement of some species from other genera. Thus, a number of morphological characters that are necessary for a diagnosis of species are often absent from earlier descriptions (Jacobus et al . 2004). Considering that since the description of
T. mikhaili
the author has collected new material of both larvae and adults from different regions of the Russian Far East, it was decided to present additional characteristics and original illustrations for larvae and adults, as well as to describe for the first time the female imago and eggs.

Material examined .
Russian Federation :
Primorye Territory
:
Holotype .
‚ôÇ imago (reared from larva). Ussuri River , 1.5 km below Utyos Mountain ,
02.VIII.1992
, T. Tiunova.

Paratypes .
5‚ôÇ 1‚ôÄ imagoes, 5‚ôÇ 1‚ôÄ subimagoes, all reared from larvae,
4 larvae , Ussuri River , 1 km below Utyos Mountain ,
04.VIII.1994
; 5‚ôÇ imagoes, 2‚ôÇ subimagoes, all reared from larvae,
1 larva , Ussuri River , Gornye Kluchi Village , 2 km below bridge , highway Vladivostok-Khabarovsk 18.VII.1996
; 1‚ôÇ imago,1 larval skin ‚ôÄ , 1 larval skin
‚ôÇ , Bolshaya Ussurka River , 1 km below Zvenigorogka Village ,
20.VII.1996
;
13 larvae , Bolshaya Ussurka River basin, Malinovka River , 50 m above bridge, highway Vladivostok-Khabarovsk ,
20.VII.1996
;
8 ‚ôÇ imagoes (light), Ilistaya River , 700 m below bridge , highway Vladivostok-Khabarovsk ,
5.VIII.2007
;
1‚ôÇ imago (light), Razdol‚Äônaya River , above Zarechnoe Village ,
4.VIII.2007
;
2‚ôÇ imagoes (light), Razdol‚Äônaya River Basin, Medveditsa River at the confluence with the Kraunovka River ,
14‚Äì15.VIII.2002
; Khabarovsk Territory :
1‚ôÇ (reared from larva), Amur River Basin , Bikin River , Zvenevoy Village ,
22.VII.1996
;
13 larvae , Bikin River , 300 m below bridge , highway Vladivostok-Khabarovsk ,
13.VII.2000
;
1‚ôÇ (reared from larva), Amur River Basin , Gur River , bridge, highway Khabarovsk-Komsomolsk,
22.VII.1996
. All material collected by T. Tiunova.

Diagnosis.
Torleya mikhaili
can be separated from the other species of the genus by the combination of the following characteristics. Male imago : (1) forceps segment II which has a slight distal expansion; (2) penis with elongated apical lobes rounded at the apex; (3) U-shape a median notch; (4) genital forceps segment III relatively short, length approximately 1.5‚Äì1.7 times the width. Larvae : (5) posterior margins of abdominal terga without paired tubercles; (6) forefemur with distal transverse row of long, stout and pointed setae; length of these setae ¬Ω of width of femur; (7) claw of fore leg with two groups of denticles; apical group with four acute and long denticles; subdistal setae absent; (8) posterolateral projection on terga IV‚ÄìIX well developed; (9) posterior margins of terga IV‚ÄìIX with paired submedian short, clavate setae. Eggs : (10) the ridges about 2‚Äì3 ¬µm in width; (11) the surface of the ridges relatively smooth.

Habitat . Larvae and adults of
T. mikhaili
were collected in the south of the Russian Far East (Primorskiy and Khabarovskiy Territories) at the beginning July‚Äìmiddle of August. Larvae were collected in rivers (
) at a depth of 30 to 100 cm. The width of the rivers in the places where larvae were collected exceeded 100 m; the length of these rivers is more than 300 km. The water temperature in this period exceeds 20‚Äì25¬∞C. The larvae inhabited stone-gravel substrates with sand and detritus, mainly in slow currents.

Remarks . In an article devoted to the revision of
Torleya species
, the authors were the first to indicate China in the distribution of
T. mikhaili (Jacobus et al ., 2004)
. At the same time, when comparing larvae from Russia and China , a number of differences were noted that arose due to the absence of some morphological characteristics in the description of
T. mikhaili
. Additional data presented in this work confirm the presence of this species in China . Note that in 2020 an article was published that provided molecular data for
T. mikhaili
larvae collected in China (
Li et al. 2020
). Therefore, a goal of further research will be to collect material for the molecular study of
T. mikhaili
from Russia so those populations can be compared to their Chinese counterparts.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Currently, the fauna of the genus
Torleya
is represented by thirteen species, which can be divided into two groups, according to the presence or absence of maxillary palp in the larvae. The species
T. longforceps
is not considered here, since its larva is unknown; therefore, it cannot be assigned to any species group based on the oral apparatus of the larva.

The
major
-group includes species in which the maxillary palp is present:
Torleya coheri
( type species of the genus group
Crinitella
, now a junior synonym of
Torleya
per
),
T. padunica
,
T. major
(the type species of
Torleya
),
T. dibruensis
and
T. elissa ;
and the nepalica- group includes species in which the maxillary palp is absent:
T. japonica
,
T. lacuna
,
T. lutosa
,
T. mikhaili , T. naga
,
T. nepalica
, and
T. simbalbarensis
(
; Jacobus et al . 2004;
;
;
).

Among species of
Torleya
with available imaginal description,
T. mikhaili
is closest to the following species, which also have genital forceps segment II with a slight distal expansion:
T. japonica , T. padunica , T. coheri
, and
T. longforceps
. The male imago of
T. mikhaili
can be distinguished by the following features: penis with elongated apical lobes rounded at the apex ( Figs 3‚Äì4 ) and U-shape a median notch (in contrast to
T. japonica
penis with short apical lobes that are very sharp at the apex,
: fig. 1; 2005: fig. 10) (in contrast to
T. coheri
and
T. longforceps
that have penis lobes short, rounded and with a V-shaped shallow, median notch;
: fig. 2;
: fig. 11‚Äì26E); genital forceps segment III relatively short (length approximately 1.5‚Äì1.7 times the width, as in Figs 3‚Äì4 ) (in contrast to
T. padunica
, which has genital forceps segment III relatively elongate, with a length 2 times the width;
: fig. 10).

Final instar larvae of
T. mikhaili
can be distinguished from the other
nepalica
-group species by the following characters: posterior margins of abdominal terga without paired tubercles ( Fig. 9 ) (in
T. lacuna
,
T. nepalica
and
T. simbalbarensis
terga with paired tubercles) (
: figs. 5, 7;
: fig. 22;
: fig. 19A); claw of fore leg without subdistal setae ( Fig. 14 ) (in
T. japonica
and
T. naga
claw of fore leg with subdistal setae); posterolateral projections on terga IV‚ÄìIX well-developed ( Figs 9 , 15 ) (in
T. naga
posterolateral projection on terga VIII‚Äì IX small) (Jacobus et al . 2004: fig.7); posterior margins of terga IV‚ÄìIX with paired, submedian, short, clavate setae ( Fig. 15 ) (in
T. japonica
posterior margins of terga IV‚ÄìVII with short, flat, very sharp, paired dorsal spines) (Jacobus et al . 2004); the dorsum of head, thorax, legs and abdomen without numerous bubble-like setae ( Figs 10, 11 ) (in contrast to
T. lutosa
) (
: fig. 7I).

At the present time, eggs of
Torleya species
are described only for
T. lutosa , T. naga , T. nepalica
,
T. major
and
T. coheri .
The eggs of all these species are very similar and have ovoid shape, with a polar cap composed of dense threads, a chorion with a geometric macrorelief constituted of large-meshed reticulations with relatively deep mesh units; each mesh unit with a flat, smooth bottom. The ridges differ in width between species. In
T. mikhaili
, the ridges are about 2‚Äì3 ¬µm in width; in
T. nepalica
4‚Äì8 ¬µm (
: fig. 21), in
T. naga
3‚Äì7 ¬µm (Jacobus et al . 2004: fig. 5), in
T. lutosa
3‚Äì7 ¬µm (
: fig. 23), in
T. major
6‚Äì7 ¬µm (
: figs 4C, 7D), and in
T. coheri
4‚Äì5 ¬µm (
: fig. 20). In
T. mikhaili
, the surface of the ridges is relatively smooth, and the inner margins of ridges have numerous papillae ( Fig. 25 ); in
T. nepalica
and
T. lutosa
, the ridges are granular (
: fig. 21 and 23, respectively).

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p: The author is grateful to Luke Jacobus ( Indiana University Purdue University Columbus, USA ) for remarks, comments and help during the preparation of the manuscript. The scanning electron micrographs were prepared with the help of Vitaliy Kazarin (Federal Scientific Center of the East Asia Terrestrial Biodiversity Far Eastern Branch, Russian Academy of Sciences, Vladivostok). The research was carried out within the state assignment of Ministry of Science and Higher Education of the Russian Federation (theme No. 124012400285-7).
